awd_titl_txt: RET in Engineering and Computer Science SITE: Research Experience for Teachers on Cyber-Enabled Technologies
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SITE-Res Exp for Tchr Site

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the NSF supported Florida International University Cyber-Enabled Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site were to (1) build long term collaborative partnerships between K-12 STEM teachers and the research community; (2) increase K-12 teachers’ knowledge of cyber-enabled technologies; (3) increase K-12 teachers’ technology competency through research and professional development programs and (4) assist teachers to develop class curricula using their experience.

During the Site grant period (2015-2017), this site provided a total of 48 (16 per year for 3 years) teacher participants, earning professional in-service credits in grades 6-12. The program targeted and trained teachers from the Miami-Dade County Public School District which is the fourth largest school district in the United States. Approximately 72% of the teachers in the school district are from minority groups, mainly Hispanic and African Americans. Also, 41% of Florida’s high minority schools, and 23.9% of the State’s high poverty schools are located in the target school district from which our teacher participants were selected.

These science teachers—all within commuting distance of FIU, had an opportunity to engage in high-quality cutting edge research during a six week summer program under the mentorship of a faculty member. More than 12 faculty members participated in the program, providing mentoring based upon their unique cultural and international backgrounds as well as their specialized computer science skills. As a result, several of the teachers were motivated to and did publish their research work, while several others continued their personal and professional education by attending graduate school.

Research projects centered on emerging cyber-enabled technologies including cloud computing, social networks, security and privacy. An important objective of the program was the transfer of the teachers’ research experience gained in the program back into their classrooms. To accomplish this, teachers met together weekly as a group, and worked closely with faculty, staff, students and each other to collectively consider ways in which they could communicate the concepts and research processes used during the summer to their students, and to develop educational modules based on their research experience through the summer.

Other career development program activities included weekly seminars, field trips, workshops and academic year follow-ups.  Under the coherent theme of cyber-enabled technologies, the site offered an effective research experience for teachers on state-of-the-art, high-quality research in fields such as social networks, cloud computing, privacy and security. The new research-based curriculum and activities implemented in the schools during the academic years encouraged development of computational-thinking competencies in schools to prepare students to join the 21st Century workforce.


Last Modified: 10/03/2018
Modified by: Niki Pissinou
